text:
This is excellent cornbread!  I use 1/3 c. white and 1/3 c. brown sugar, and I let the cornmeal soak in the milk for 10-15 minutes before mixing with the other ingredients.  I've also replaced the vegetable oil with melted butter, which works very well.

text:
Well, needles to say, you'd sure be hard pressed to come up with a better cornbread recipe.  It's excellent!  Suberb! I've read all 84 + reviews and have learned the following additional options:  I can bake it in a muffin pan (bake only 15 minutes); I can cut back on my sugar to maybe a round 1/2-cup (or less).  I can add just a smidgen more salt.  I can add a 1/2 t. vanilla.  Add I can also add just a little bit more oil (so it's not quite so crumbly).  The next time I bake this for our gang, I'm going to add all of the above -- I'll be bold and daring!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This works as cornbread muffins, too!  I am not a huge fan of making cornbread as a round or square cake shape… they just are too messy that way.  Instead I like to pour the batter into muffin tins lined with cupcake/muffin papers.  This recipe works great as muffins.  I pour the batter almost to the very top of the paper liners then I bake this at 375 degrees, but I have a convection oven so the heat is usually 25 degrees less than the normal temperature… so you can cook it at the suggested heat of 400 degrees with a normal oven.  It takes 20-23 minutes for a toothpick to come out clean.  The tops are always nicely browned and the muffins are perfectly cooked.  The only other minor change I make is I use a medium grind cornmeal that is a little more course.  It makes the cornbread more like a true “comfort food”.  If you don’t like that extra crunch then use a finer grind.  EVERYONE loves this- it is always on request from my guests and family,  “Can you make your special cornbread?”  It only takes about 5 minutes if you use a stand mixer.  Very easy and very yummy!  People will love that you made this from scratch.  Oh yeah, and for you calorie nuts: I have calculated that if you make 12 muffins out of this batter, it runs about 180 calories per muffin or 2160 for the whole batch.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe except I added a generous amount of black pepper and cooked it in an 8" cast iron skillet (which increased the cooking time somewhat).  We thought it was wonderful!  Nice and moist and just sweet enough.  I will say technique does help. It really does make a difference using a cast iron skillet. Grease it generously, but not too much or your bread will crumble.  Preheat your oven and put the cast iron skillet in before you start making the cornbread.  It needs 10-15 minutes to get good and hot.  You want to hear that "sizzle" when you pour the batter in.  That makes a wonderful crust on the outside with a nice moist bread on the inside!  When making the mix, whisk your dry ingredients together to make sure everything is evenly distributed. Then mix your wet ingredients together (just whisk with a fork) in a separate bowl before adding them to the dry ingredients.  Don't beat the mixture to death, just mix and fold gently till everything is wet. Then let it sit for 5 minutes before pouring into the nice hot cast iron skillet...yum!

text:
Oh my goodness--this is wonderful! Absolutely better than boxed mix (and without that funny little aftertaste you get from boxed cornbread).  This is the only cornbread recipe I will ever need.  If you like sweet cornbread rather than unsweetened cornbread and you're looking for a good recipe, look no more--this is the one! I read some reviews that noted cumbliness, so I added a little extra vegetable oil (very little extra--I just let the measuring cup overflow a tad). Also, I cut the salt to 1/2 teaspoon rather than 1 teaspoon.  I don't know if that's the reason, but it turned out super moist without any crumbling apart whatsoever--just those few cornbread crumbs that fall as you slice.  Perfection!!! Thank you!!!!

text:
**Update** I've been making this for over a year now and have found new ways to use it. For corn muffins, don't use paper liners. Instead, use cooking spray and be generous. Then pour the batter right in. Your muffins will have a nice crisp browned crust. Yum! I also jazz the muffins by adding leftover pulled pork or (in mini-muffins) bits of hot dogs. The pulled pork muffins are amazing, thanks Chef John! Keep mustard on hand for dipping mini corn dog muffins, Kids gobble them up. Both are major winners! ** Original review - Made this tonight, subbing a combo of GF baking mix and GF bread flour for the AP flour. Everything else per recipe. Whole family loved it. DH loves Marie Callendar cornbread and said this is one I need to make again. BTW - I'm the only one who eats gluten free, the rest of the pack, DH, DS, DDIL and grands are all wheat-eaters. Even the 2 yr-old loved it. A definite winner. Thank you!

userID:
2077374
Display Name:
Nowal J.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/2414.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only reason I didn't give a full five stars was that the texture was crumbly; otherwise, this recipe makes an excellent, moderately sweet cornbread.  I followed the recipe to the letter, with the exception of baking it in a 10" cast iron skillet. I let the empty skillet heat up in the oven as it preheated and made sure the oven temp got up to 400 (I have an oven thermometer -- so should you). Then, I melted a little butter in the skillet to coat it, and poured in the batter. This resulted in a very nice, crunchy brown crust and a moist interior -- just the way I like it.  I baked the cornbread for exactly 20 minutes, but wonder if I could have gone for even less time, thanks to the heat-retaining cast iron.  Next time, I will modify this recipe by (1) heating the milk to scalding and soaking the cornmeal in it, and (2) adding an egg to the recipe.  One final note: I used the full amount of baking powder, but used an aluminum-free brand. Perhaps the reason people have reported off-flavors is not because of using too much baking powder, but because they are using baking powder that contains aluminum and gives a bitter flavor to baked goods anyway.

text:
I read all the  reviews on this recipes and took them at heart. I lowered the sugar to 1/2 cup, 1/4 cup white & 1/4 cup brown sugar. Then cut it back even further to use Splenda sugars. Cut the baking soda down to 2 tsp. and soaked the corn meal in the milk and used the butter instead of veg. oil. Baked them in a muffin pan and got 12 muffins. Husband and I just loved them. Gave the recipes 5 stars even with the changes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have any cornmeal but I really wanted cornbread with my chili FAST. So I used this recipe as a guideline and threw together what I had. I LOVED it, and so did my family! I will make it the "fake" way again cause it was so good. I used the same recipe as here except with a few substitutions. Instead of 1 c flour and 1 c cornmeal, I used 1 1/3 c flour and 1/3 cup of MALT-O-MEAL!! WOW! It was great, I never would have thought it would turn out so good. I even used maple flavored because that it what I had, wonderful! I added 1/3 cup of white corn, some cardamom, and white pepper. I reduced the vegetable oil by half. I also added a tbsp of honey. I baked it in a buttered muffin pan. It baked for only 25 minutes before it was done to a toothpick test, but my oven is wacky so you might want to keep an eye on it. I highly recommend trying it this way if, like me, you almost always have malt-o-meal and never have any cornmeal around.

text:
WOW. That's really all I can say. When I was a kid, this type of delicious cornbread was a common staple where I lived in southern Jersey. I was a child, and so I naively thought all cornbread was the same. Sadly, I was mistaken, and when I moved to Georgia when I was 9, I was introduced to Southern Cornbread. It was dry and salty and tasted more like I was chewing on a dirt clod than anything else. At first, I thought maybe it was just a bad batch, but from the way everyone was raving over it, I quickly realized that the Southerners have an extremely different taste than I do. I thought this type of cornbread was lost to me forever, but I am SO GLAD to have been mistaken! THANK YOU. No longer will I have to suffer through politely eating that disgusting clump of dough they dare to call cornbread at church functions. Now I can show them how cornbread is SUPPOSED to taste: good.

text:
I wish I could give this recipe something like 4 1/2 stars, because I really loved it. The sweetness was perfect (tasted the batter and it was SWEET; I was worried, but the finished bread was fantastic). It was nice and moist, and the directions and baking time were spot on. My only issue is that the bread was almost too fluffy, which resulted in it also being pretty crumbly. I'll decrease the baking powder a bit next time and see what happens. At any rate - We ate it slathered with butter and honey, and even though we had to eat it with forks because of the crumble factor, it was divine.

text:
Delicious. 24 minutes was perfect for me. The trick to moist cornbread is to top it off with honey in a crosshatch pattern (you can reduce the sugar in the actual recipe if it makes it too sweet, but I like it sweet). This will keep the cornbread moist for another day. YUM! Great with chili, great alone! Thank you.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
5417032
Display Name:
potaytou
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
13
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just finished making this (this happens to be my first time making cornbread ever, as it's not well-known here- you can't even find it anywhere in restaurants).  Anyhow, I'm on a dairy and egg-free diet and a restricted wheat diet, so I substituted the AP flour for Gluten-free flours from Bob's Red Mill (garbanzo bean, rice, sorghum, potato flours, etc) and 1 tsp of vital wheat gluten (I know it's wheat, but it's only 1 tsp as opposed to an entire cup), unsweetened soy milk and 1/4 cup silken tofu for the egg. I also used a rounded 1/2 cup sugar, added 1/2 tsp vanilla and very slightly more than 1/3 cup oil (I used grapeseed so it would be a lighter oil, since non-wheat flours can have a hard time rising properly).  Took it out of the oven at 25 minutes and the edges were browned nicely and crunchy, but not burnt at all and it had risen very well, looked just like regular light and fluffy wheat flour when I cut into it. I couldn't help myself and took a first piece while it was still steaming hot. Scrumptious! Maybe the only thing I would do next time is add the normal amount of sugar if I wanted it a bit sweeter, but as it is, it has a very mild sweetness and a very pleasant texture. The odd time you can feel a bit of the cornmeal grainy texture, but that's half the fun of eating it, I think. I finished off the entire row I cut into in one sitting. I will definitely make this again, and the recipe is so easy and almost fool-proof it seems.

None
text:
Yum! This is a fantastic sweet cornbread. Like other reviewers, I soaked the cornmeal in the milk for about ten minutes before combining all of the ingredients, and added just a touch more oil to the batter. Before baking, I put 1/2 a teaspoon or so of vegetable oil into each of eight mini-loaf tins, and tossed the tins into the oven. Once the oil was hot, I filled the tins about halfway and then baked them for 18 minutes at 400; they turned out perfectly! Nice and sweet, crunchy on the outside and not overly crumbly inside. So easy to make, that these will definitely be making appearances at my dinnertable more often.

BOOKIE 
isPro:

city:

region:

country:

text:
1 23 15 ...http://allrecipes.com/recipe/17891/golden-sweet-cornbread/ ... With a few changes - decreasing sugar to 1/3c & baking powder to 2t - this is the one L & E (7 yrs) like better (than Homesteader).  They are both good, but this is the sweeter choice.------ I tried the soaking the cornmeal trick.  It seemed like a good idea.  The result was a dry cornbread.  Not extremely dry.  No need to reach for the butter :D, but definately a difference.  It wasn't crumbly, but didn't make clean cuts either.  So, if you feel the need to soak, you should add more oil.  As for me, I'm not soaking, sticking with less sugar & less baking powder.  When it's done, it's just browning around the edges; probably have a rectangular-shaped cracked top; roundtop, not flat.  3/12: Tried half cup whole wheat flour, half cup white & it wasn't too "brown"  :D  Since I used white cornmeal, it helped the color, too - looking more like cornbread instead of unfrosted cake.  :)  Note4Me:  Pale using white cornmeal.  25 mins in 9x13 glass. Rounded top.  A rectangular slight crack.

text:
I've used this recipe for a couple years now, and it has never disappointed me. Since I'm cutting back on calories these days, I replace the all-purpose flour with white whole wheat flour, use 1/3 cup of honey in place of sugar, 3 TB of egg white for the egg, almond milk in place of cow's milk, and applesauce for the veggie oil. I've even baked this batter in muffin tins for perfect small portions. Great with chili on a cold fall day.

text:
Good, but I think I will continue to use the recipe on the Quaker box of Golden Corn Meal. 1  1/2 c corn meal, 1/2 c flour, 1/4 c sugar, 1/2 tsp salt, 4 tsp baking powder, 1 egg, 1 c milk, 1/4 c vegetable oil. Beat only until there are some small lumps remaining. Pour into greased 8" pan. Bake 425 F 20-25 minutes.

Excellent. Cooked up beautifully. I always use a trick my grandmother did with her cornbread. While you are preheating your oven place a cast iron skillet with a little vegetable oil in it. When hot pour in cornbread mixture. This gives a beautiful crisp crust on the outside. I did use stone ground cornbread that I buy in the Texas Hill Country. Thanks!

text:
Made this last night to go with our chili, and it was excellent!  I'd been looking for a copycat Boston Market cornbread recipe that didn't start with a mix and stumbled across this recipe.  It is even better than theirs!  I made muffins, and added slightly more oil per other reviewers.  Will definitely be my go-to cornbread recipe!

UPDATE:  I've made this cornbread quite a few times now and it really is best exactly as written.  I like to make them as muffins.  I found this recipe when I was looking for a Boston Market copycat cornbread recipe, but I didn't want to use all the mixes that recipe calls for.  This is a great, from-scratch substitute!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This does make some very good cornbread, although I did find it to be slightly too sweet. (That is the only reason it is a 4 star for me)

I loved the texture. This turned out to be very light and fluffy. Almost cake like. I cooked mine in a cast iron skillet and I was worried at first because you could smell the sugar immediately as it was cooking. I was afraid it was going to come out burned but it came out perfectly fine. It does fall apart very easily though and is better suited to making as muffins.

If you like to crumble your cornbread into soups and stews, this does not work as well for that. It is way too soft and it immediately turns soggy. I am use to my cornbread staying somewhat firm and keeping some of its crispy pieces (from the top and edges of the cornbread) when I put it in soups or stews.

Bottom line is this was very good despite its sweetness. I will make this again, as muffins to have as a side, but this will nto be the cornbread I make for soups. I will also cut back on the sugar.

text:
Deeeelicous! Says it makes 12 servings, but I just ate 1/3 of it myself.   I've loved cornbread since I was young, but always made it with Jiffy Mix.  I didn't have any of that in the house, & wanted cornbread this morning (We had cornmeal in cupboard from a recent fish-fry).  I went online & found this recipe; I'll probably never by a pre-made mix again.

There was only about a 1/3 cup white sugar in our cupboard, so I used that & a 1/3 cup brown sugar.  Also, we only have whole wheat flour, so I used that.  I always use refrigerated bacon grease to grease the pan - adds just a hint of bacon flavor.

I usually top my cornbread with butter & honey, or mash it up with heated milk and sugar.  I tried a small bite of this when I took it out of the oven and decided it needed nothing but that dab of butter.

text:
I followed the recipe as written twice, and both times my cornbread was dry.  Since then I have made two changes: 1/3 brown sugar and 1/3 white, instead of all white sugar, and I bake at 375 degrees for about 35 minutes.  By far the best cornbread I've ever had, it flies off the table!  Thank you for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm hard to please when it comes to cornbread.  For me, a good cornbread recipe has to walk a very fine line.  It has to be sweet enough that the cornmeal itself is not overwhelming, but not too sweet that it becomes more of a dessert or breakfast bread than something that could be served alongside supper.  Besides that, I don't like it too grainy, but I also don't want it to be too cakey.  A good cornbread recipe must be middle of the road in those two areas.  This recipe fit the bill perfectly.  It was sweet enough, but not too sweet, had marvelous texture, and was wonderfully moist.  I will use this recipe again.  Thank you.

Very tasty; I baked mine in a muffin tin and it took 18 minutes @ 400.    I added a pinch of cayenne, 1/4tsp of chili powder, and ~3/4c frozen corn.  I also bumped up the salt to a 1.5tsp (total)  Moist, sweet, delicious!  Note: Be sure to grease AND flour the pan otherwise you will find yourself running a knife around the baking vessel.

text:
This cornbread recipe rocks!!!  I make it all the time.  I make a few modifications:  I use brown sugar instead of white, and reduce measurement to to 1/2 cup; I sub in wheat free flours for the all purpose, due to wheat issues; I use olive oil instead of regular vegetable oil and sometimes I halve the oil measurement and put in some applesauce; I use vanilla soy milk instead of regular milk.  

It's great with chili, for breakfast,or a nutritious snack.

text:
I just made this bread. Came out excellent. My adjustments were (2) eggs instead of one, (a tad bit) more sugar, (2 1/2) baking powder instead of 3 1/2 tsps, and I added (3) tablespoons more oil in addition to the 1/3 cup --- based on recommendations by other reviewers.  Came out DELICIOUS.  I'm using this as "my official" cornbread recipe now.  I'd lost my old one and this one sounded very similar.  

Only, I cook on a gas stove and I had to take it out before the 25 mins... the bottom burned a little. So next time I'll monitor it closely and adj. my baking time.  Otherwise, it came out excellent.

text:
Excellent! my moms recipe is very similar but there are differences, hers has only 3 TBLS of sugar so I was a little concerned it would be to sweet for our taste, so I cut the sugar to 1/3 cup and used 3 tsp of baking powder per others suggestions and I thought it was terrific Next time I make it I am going to use a trick from my moms recipe, she melts bacon grease into the pan that you will be cooking the cornbread in and then add 3-4 Tbls of the melted bacon grease into the batter and cook, it adds a great taste  and it is not greasy, gives it a beautiful golden color thanx for a great recipe!!!! the only difference in her recipe is that it calls for 1/2 cup of flour and4 tsp of baking powder, I think Lori's recipe makes a bigger fluffer cornbread so I would think the bacon grease would work just as well, I will try it that way next time and let you know GREAT!!!!!!! GREAT!! try this one folks!!!

text:
I made muffins from this recipe.  I followed the recipe for the batter to the letter.  I used butter on my muffin pan, and the muffins were done with golden brown bottoms in about 15 minutes.  They came right out of the pan, so I'm using butter from now on.  I set my timer for 20 minutes, so it was a good thing I peeked in on them early!  I didn't have muffin liners, but would have been hesitant to use them, since they seem stick to the finished product and leave you with less muffin to enjoy.  I thought they might be too sweet with the 2/3 cup of sugar, but they were fine.

text:
I loved this recipe...but didn't make it exactly the way the recipe said.  I used half and half (but would have used buttermilk if I'd had it...I added lemon juice to half and half for the same effect)...and I added a cup of frozen corn kernels.  I greased cast iron skillet with bacon grease and heated until smoking hot, then added batter and sprinkled with sea salt before putting into oven to bake.  Would be great with mix ins like bell peppers and onions and jalapenos...or basil and tomatoes and parm or asiago or romano cheeses...I am sooooooooooo going to experiment with it.  Love the basic recipe...so easy and wonderful!  By the way, this really reminded me of corn dog batter!  It was missing a bit of butter though I thought.  I remedied this with topping it with melted butter and a little more salt before eating but I think substituting butter for oil in batter might fix that.  It was very good even the way it was!  Great recipe!

Restaurant quality recipe. If you use an earthenware baking dish and this can be cooked on the upper level of a gas grill on those hot summer nights. But set this up in indirect heat while grilling country style spare ribs, with a quick cajun rice on the grill side burner and you are 30 minutes from a quick filling meal without heating up the kitchen!

text:
I made it using 1/2c white sugar and the rest of the 1/3c sugar as brown sugar. It made 6 regular-sized muffins and 24 minis, and I'm waiting for the mini muffins to cool down so I can taste this! (The batter was great, so I've got high hopes for these little guys.)
If you're making mini-muffins, 12 minutes is a good amount of time to bake evenly all the way through. I wasn't the most even in my batter distribution (some are noticeably taller than others) but they all baked all the way through in about 12 minutes.
....they've cooled enough, lemme at 'em! And the verdict is...delicious! Making these was a great way to christen my mini-muffin pan. :)
I think next time, though, I'm gonna sprinkle sanding sugar on them. I do tend to prefer my cornbread a little sweeter. I can't wait to make these again!

text:
More like 4-1/2 stars.  I made this as written, using King Arthur's Whole Wheat Flour in a cast iron skillet AND made Grandmother's Buttermilk Cornbread as written and served them both at a small get-together.  Of the people there, 6 preferred Grandmother's.  May have been the WW flour or maybe just the recipe.  So, I'm knocking a star off this since I also preferred Grandmother's. Don't get me wrong, this is an excellent recipe, but I will probably make it once more with regular flour.  Can't really go wrong here...certainly better than boxed and very easy too!  Using cast iron definitely gives the crust a nice crunchy texture and the cake-part was perfect.  Just don't over-beat.

text:
Made mine "free" of almost everything but taste-- and served as heart-shaped muffins for Valentine's Day dinner :)
Used Gluten free flour, fine polenta, 1/2c agave, coconut oil (liquefied & added last to avoid re-solidifying), & almond milk. Reduced salt to 3/4 tsp. Added 1 cup frozen corn (chopped in Magic Bullet).
Baked at 350- 10 mins, then turned pans and baked for 5-8 mins more, watching closely.
Made 12 moist, yummy muffins

This is the first time I have ever made corn bread from scratch. I stuck to the recipe mostly, just used melted butter for the oil and an egg replacer since my son is allergic to eggs. I made them into muffins and only baked them for 15 minutes. They were moist and so yummy. My husband, who doesn't usually like cornbread, actually had two. Nice to find a good recipe on the first try!

Display Name:
wind_in_the_willow

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum Yum!  Everyone in my family loved it!  (Age 3-30!)  ONly reason im not giving 5 stars is cause I felt I needed to tweak a lot... but EXCELLENT base recipe that you can change a little here and there each time.  Keeps things interesting I think!  

Heres how I did it---I followed the advice of others and let the milk soak in the corneal for a bit before adding the egg and then other ingrediants.  I also subsituted butter for oil and half the flour as whole wheat flour.  I decreased the sugar to just under a half cup and decreased baking powder to just under 2...After mixing all ingrediants the mixture seemed too thick so I winged it and added a little more milk and maybe a tblsp of veg oil. Next time I'm gonna try NOT soaking the cormeal and milk and see if this helps with the thickness of the mix.

 I cooked in a butter Pam sprayed pyrex pie dish and it took 30 mins to get golden.  

Great with butter on top or without.

I made this last night to accompany a Southwestern style black bean soup for a group of friends that were coming over.  It was the perfect accompaniment. I don't know how often I'll buy the package mix now that I have this recipe.  Really easy to bring together and done from start to eating in 25 minutes.  You can't ask for better or faster.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful tasting batter!  I had extra blueberries, and a craving for cornbread.  Was inspired by this allrecipes entry:  http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/blueberry-cornmeal-muffins/detail.aspx

I used the batter from this, used melted butter instead of oil, 1/3 brown and 1/3 white sugar, and added blueberries!  YUM!

Here are my grandmother's tips:

Reserve 2 tbs of the flour and 2 tsp of the white sugar.  

Use a silicone pan, and spray lightly with cooking spray, then sprinkle lightly with white sugar to coat.

Blend all ingredients as stated, let stand for 2 mins, while you dredge the berries in the extra flour.  Fold the berries in the batter - CAREFULLY! - right before spooning into the pan!

These browned a little uneven, so I would turn down the oven to 375 and bake a few mins more.

WONDERFUL, and came right out of the pan!  Just a tad dry/crumbly, so maybe more milk? I didn't mind eating it like cobbler with butter on top!

text:
This recipe makes a very good sweet cornbread base. I made a few tweeks because I wanted to be sure that it came out fluffy and moist. I used two teaspoons of baking powder and one teaspoon of baking soda. I used one cup of vanilla flavored almond milk and 2/3 cup soy sour cream. It came out very nice. It took about 33 minutes to bake. I baked it at 400 for the first 18 minutes and then finished baking it at 390 for 15 more minutes. Tastes very good. It came out very most inside and thankfully not wet like a fruit cake. The crust on the outside came slightly crisp which added joy to the eating experience. Overall I'm thankful for this recipe allowed me to make a cake-like cornbread which is exactly what I was hoping for.

Display Name:
MAMALEIGH

city:

country:

text:
After reading review after review that mentioned how "crumbly" this cornbread is, I wondered if I had been wrong in my assumption that all cornbread is a little crumbly.  Isn't that part of its down-home charm?  So, I threw this recipe together as written, though I did have to substitute brown sugar for about a quarter cup of the white sugar (I ran out).  It looked and smelled delicious when I pulled the piping hot pan out of the oven.  And the taste - well, it's nothing short of divine.  Probably the best-tasting cornbread I've ever made.  The texture?  In short, it's CRUMBLY.  Not your basic cornbread crumbly, but difficult to pick up crumbly.  Thus, the four stars.  I still loved this recipe and will try it again with a few changes to help ward off the crumbs.

text:
This was amazing, but as per usual, I made a few adjustments. I found that if I used 1/3 cup Splenda, the bread was plenty sweet. I also used egg substitute, whole wheat flour, and lowfat buttermilk instead of eggs, all-purpose, and milk. I also used applesauce in replace of the oil, which added a bit of the sweetness back without making the bread taste like apples. Lastly, I stirred a few forkfuls of drained julienned sun-dried tomatoes (jarred in oil) into the mix and baked for 22 minutes. It came out perfect: moist, sweet, with a bit of a tart bite from the tomatoes. Soooo good!

text:
I am a Vegan and  I made this cornbread, (with milk and egg replacements of course) and it was the most delicious cornbread I ever had.  this is how I altered it...


Golden Sweet Cornbread (Vegan Style)

1 cup White Wheat flour
1 cup Yellow Cornmeal
1/2 cup Unrefined sugar(i used turbinado)
1 tsp salt
3 1/2 tsp baking powder
1 Tbs Ground Golden Flaxseeds mixed with 3 Tbs. Water.
1 cup soymilk (add 1 tsp vinegar to make buttermilk)
1/3 cup oil.


This came out perfect!!! I will be sharing this will all of my fellow Vegans,... of course giving you the credit! lol   Thanx for such a great recipe.

text:
We loved this!  I have a family history of elevated chlorestrol so this recipe made with oil was perfect.  I made some subsitutions.  As other raters suggested, I soaked the cornmeal in milk for 15 minutes.  I use a 50/50 mix of white flour and whole wheat.  Also used 50/50 mix of Splenda and brown sugar.   I added 3/4 cup of my mom's home grown sweet corn.  I substituted 1 whole egg with 2 egg whites.  I had enough batter to fill 12 mini muffin cups and put the remaining in a loaf pan...perfect. Because of the addition of the sweet corn I found that I had to bake the loaf pan an extra 10 minutes.   Great recipe and I will make this again and again.

text:
I should have taken more caution when I saw all the variations to the original, supposedly, five-star recipe. My wife usually uses Jiffy and adds a little cream corn and butter, but being Christmas Eve everything was closed and we really wanted some cornbread to go along with our smoked ribs, collard greens, and mac and cheese. So I Googled for the best cornbread recipe and this came at the top of Google's SEO (I really can't figure that one out). When I put the tray in the oven at 400° exactly like it said, the bread was already burning at about 17 minutes. When I tried the cornbread at the dinner table I immediately noticed a bitter and burning sensation in the back of my throat. My wife suggested that it could be the result of too much baking soda. So I looked up some other recipes and three and a half teaspoons of baking soda seems to be a little much - see the numerous reviews of people who would cut that down almost in half to 2 teaspoons. Not sure why everybody wants to add their own or take away to a crappy recipe. Why don't you just find a good recipe and stick to exactly what they say to do. Maybe I will post my wife's recipe sometime here soon. I cannot get the poisonous taste out of my throat.  Merry Christmas.

So I totally stumbled onto this recipe by accident. I made a big pot of greens tonight (a lot of work for a weeknight but they were in sale for $1.50 a bunch so I couldn't  pass them up). Well anyway I reached in the pantry for the cornbread mix that starts with a j and ends with a y. Low and behold I didn't have any. I'm like what am I going to do? text:
Can someone please explain to me what in the actual f***? I made this recipe with the suggestions of 1/2 tsp salt and 2 tsp baking powder, and I heated up a cast iron skillet enough to melt some butter for the coating. Also, we only had unsweetened vanilla almond milk on hand, but since it is supposed to substitute the same, I wasn't too worried, and I let the cornmeal soak in it while I got everything else ready.

I can't compare it to the recipe as listed but I can't imagine anything tasting much better. Get how perfect this is. Not only is it simple, takes less than five minutes to prep and only 20 to bake, my second time making it I completed omitted the oil. (I am a literal potato.)

  Devastated, I took the pan out 15 mins in and cut into it. To my surprise the knife came out clean. With the structural integrity intact, I figured it must be too dense or dry or crumbly. Tasted it. STILL PERFECT. Perfect without a 'staple' ingredient? Yep. Saving this recipe. 

I love sweet cornbread and usually top mine with honey, but with this recipe all I need is a little salted butter. New go time snack for tea. Sorry, waistline.

text:
Great recipe. I've used it at least 3 times.  I would give this 5 Stars except for two things. It was a bit dry in texture and wasn't very sweet to me (not how I like anyhow). I took someone else's advice and added more oil (about 1/2 cup instead of 1/3) to combat the dryness. I also added some honey to the batter (not a lot; I made a squiggle so I'm not sure...maybe 1-2 tsp). All the difference! Overall, this is a really good starting space for those new to making cornbread.

text:
AWESOME. AWESOME AWESOME.

My only changes were to use a 1/3 cup brown and a 1/3 cup white sugar instead of just white. Also, cornbread pro tip: let your cornmeal soak in the milk for ~15 minutes before you mix it in. Also let your finished batter sit for 4-5 minutes before you pour it in the pan. Stir it again and then pour + bake. You'll end up with amazing, fluffy bread. Huge hit in my house. And don't listen to the person who said it crumbles too easily; it's no fault of the recipe.

text:
400° burnt the bread :-( So I recommend 
   - 375° ? (40 miners doubled)
   - Buttermilk (instead of milk)
   - Butter (instead of oil)
   - Raw sugar (instead of white, or brown its has a stronger molasses flavor)
   - Soak the cornmeal in the milk for 10+ min

*And the biggest suggestion, doubble the recipe because it is SOOO GOOD! Thanks @Bluegirl!!!

You cannot begin to imagine how simple this recipe is or how great it tastes,until you try it.I make this every single week,it's a must have for my husband,and all his friends at work figure that his wife is such a great cook after tasting this cornbread.I use brown sugar instead of white,and I cover the pan with foil while it's baking to make it really moist.I sometimes add some canned corn for the extra crunch,but it's great as is.It's FANTABULOUS!!

I love how this turned out!  I always add less sugar than recommended, so I used 1/2 a cup of Turbinado sugar.  I used Bob's Red Mill Polenta (corn grits) instead of a Quaker type cornmeal.  Lastly, I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil.   I will definitely make this again as it was quick and easy.

I just used this recipe tonight. As i was getting the ingredients together I realized I didn't have any all purpose flour but I really wanted cornbread tonight so I used the cake flour I have on hand. The cornbread turned out so fluffy and moist.I almost felt like I was cheating on the cornbread and milk adage we all grew up with.Along with the cake flour I doubled the recipe and added 1/3 cup more sugar b/c the batter was a bit bitter. My kids and wife loved it as well and told me I have to make it again

text:
This is DELICIOUS cornbread! My hubby is a born & raised southern boy and he loves his sweet cornbread (as I do, too!).  He just told me to never buy the box mix anymore (which was his favorite forever!).  As so many other reviews suggested:  I let the corn meal and milk soak while I prepared everything else.  Note:  my hubby is a diabetic and also must restrict sodium soooo I used 1/2 t. salt, 2 t. low sodium baking powder, a splash more oil and substituted Splenda's "white" sugar blend for baking.  Winner, winner!!!

text:
Great recipe! Like other reviewers I used 1/3 cup of white sugar and 1/3 cup of brown sugar instead of all white sugar. I also soaked the cornmeal in the milk for 10 minutes before mixing in other ingredients. 

This recipe also makes exactly 12 muffins if you want to make muffins instead of in a bread/cake pan. Just fill them up to about 1/4 inch from the top of the muffin cup (with paper liners). For me, they were done in 20 minutes at 400 degrees.

text:
This was, by far, the best cornbread I have ever had! And cornbread is something I LOVE! I followed a ton of reviews and got a super-moist, tasty cornbread. Advice I followed: Soaked cornmeal in milk, used melted butter instead of veg oil (and I added a little over a T more than called for) and more salt.  I also took someone else's advice and put the pan in the oven with a T of butter until it was hot and bubbly before adding the batter. Nice, buttery crust all around the edges... absolute must try!

Tweak alert! I used 1/3 cup agave instead of sugar. Because of this sub I had to use just a titch less milk. I found the bread a little crumbly but maybe it's supposed to be that way. Cornbread is not typical where I live so I don't really know how it should be. I do know that this was delish and especially good right out of the oven. I had some Portugal peppers in my freezer so I added one chopped to spice it up a bit. I will make this again. Thank you bluegirl

text:
I have made this recipe quite a few times. I love it!
I made some small changes though as I am vegan. I found that if I used unsweetened vanilla soy milk, it added a nice sweet flavor but wasn't overpowering. I cut the sugar to 1/4 cup and used just a touch of agave. I also used corn flour instead of cornmeal and an egg-replacer. This makes a moist and not-crumbly-at-all, super awesome cornbread!

text:
I just baked these using the suggested 1/3 c white & 1/3 c brown sugar instead of 2/3 c white.  I also soaked the cornmeal at least 15 min in the cup of milk first. I used an equal mix of walnut oil and coconut oil in place of the 1/3 c vegetable oil. I sprayed a muffin tin then used paper cups and the batter made 12 muffins.  Baked 18 min. in 400 degree oven and knife came out clean.  Lightly browned tops.  Delicious!

text:
For you Diabetics, or Cbef's, substitute sugar for 1/3 cup of sugar substitute(1/3 of sugar). Also for lactose intolerance and gluten issues, substitute the Milk for Almond Milk, same volume for added flavor, less flaky, and the same fulfilling flavor plus vitamins. Also makes it more of a cornbread cake using almond milk, sweet or unsweetened. Sweetened, you don't need any sugar at all!

text:
I feel there is way too much baking soda inthis recipe.  I thought 3 1/2 teaspoons was a lot, but the first two reviews – all I had read – raved about it, so I followed it. Boy, was that a mistake. Even my three-year-old daughter, who has never met a carbohydrate she doesn't love, said, "I don't like this." Basically, it tasted like delicious cornbread that had been ruined by baking soda.  Definitely reduce the amount; I will try again with 2 teaspoons.

text:
YES! I've been trying to make good cornbread for months now, with mixed success. This recipe hit a home run. I reduced the sugar to 1/2 cup and the baking soda to 2 tsp. I sprayed a muffin tin with non-stick spray and the batter filled the 12 cups exactly. After 17 minutes the corn muffins were nicely browned on the bottom, with a crisp exterior and a chewy interior. PERFECT. I resisted making other changes to the recipe, but I want to try other sweeteners (like agave or honey) and maybe adding some corn to the batter. But since it turned out so delicious, maybe I should just leave well enough alone! Thank you for this recipe.

I've been making cornbread for most of my life, but grew tired of my same-o, same-o recipe. This was a delightful find. I've made it several times for potlucks and have gone home with an empty plate! Not long ago I decided to make a pan just for me. I assemble the ingredients right into the bowl and then realized I didn't have any milk. Bummer..., but oh well I used water instead. This recipe is every bit as good with water as it is with milk. I don't think it effected the taste or texture at all. Thank you for a great recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will never buy Jiffy again!  This didn't take any longer to prepare than a boxed mix, and the ingredients are pronounceable and safe.  After reading the reviews, I decided to modify the recipe a little.  I used 1/4 cup white sugar and 1/3 cup packed brown sugar.  I also reduced the baking powder to 2 tsp, and I used 1/3 cup melted, salted butter instead of vegetable oil.  I baked it in a greased 9" round cake pan for 20 minutes at the recommended temperature.  The cornbread turned out beautifully!  It was moist, thick, and not too sweet even when dressed with honey.  My husband said, "This is the best cornbread I've ever had!"  I'm sold, too.

text:
This is the BEST recipe for sweet cornbread that I have ever tasted!!  My husband loves it also!!  We are absolutely addicted to it!!  I have also made them into muffins as they are easier to eat that way.  I found with my oven if I made the cake I needed to leave it in for 30 minutes.  If I made it into muffins 20 monies seems to be the apprppopriate amount of time for the muffins to be done.  I would suggest moms who want to put these on their kids lunches to try making the muffins...as they pack much easier.  These muffins really freeze well and defrost really well.  Making them into muffins also makes them easier to put in the freezer.

text:
Excellent cornbread! I make a couple of small changes: First, I use 1/3 cup of Cane Sugar and 1/3 cup of brown sugar, and then I exchange 1/3 cup of unsweetened applesauce and 1/6 cup of Canola oil for the 1/3 cup vegetable oil, which makes the cornbread more moist. People say it tastes like fresh corn on the cob :)

text:
Though I haven't tried any other cornbread recipes, this one turned out perfect.  We followed the recipe to the T, and I don't know what I'd change, if anything.  It is a hair sweet, but that's the point of this recipe, hence the name!  If you wanted it less sweet you could cut the sugar in half.  Personally I think cornbread tastes better sweet rather than bland and crumbly.  I made this in a 12-cupcake pan and it was the perfect amount of batter.  We will definitely use this recipe from now on.

This cornbread recipe is fantastic! I only tweaked it a little by reducing the sugar to 1/3 cup, added a tad of vanilla and used lowfat buttermilk I had leftover in my freezer...the batter is just enough for 12 muffins I honestly couldn't stand waiting the 15 mins for them to come out of the oven! Sooo, I saved some leftover batter and cooked it like you would pancakes on a hot griddle...cornbread flapjacks with some butter and honey...I just about died an am anxiously waiting for a muffin now! All I have to say is NOM NOMMER-NOM NOMS!!!

text:
I Cut the sugar to 1/2 c. And used a splenda/sugar mixture...and it was still too sweet.I can taste sugar more than corn! I used light butter/oil combo to make 1/3 cup, and 3 tsp baking powder to make it less crumbly, as others suggested. the texture was excellent, so next time I would cut the sugar even more.

region:

country:

text:
Oh my!  Was looking for a great base recipe and this was it.  Of course my twist included everything but the kitchen sink.  Basically I go by what I have on hand.  No AP flour so used Self Rising w/o the baking powder or soda.  Need it sweet so substituted 1/3 cup light brown sugar, 1/3 agave nectar, oh and 1/3 of a pack instant vanilla (sugar free) pudding which helps to keep it sweet, moist and together)  She's nuts!!! No No No! It works.  Then an overly full tablespoon of chopped jalapeno peppers, about 1/2 cup cooked and chopped up whole kernel corn, and 1/3 of a cup low fat yogart.  OK that's enough.  Not!  After mixing and filling pan, topped it off with sprinkles of real bacon bits.  The aroma alone will kill ya!  Brought it over to my picky neighbors who inhaled it.  Ahhh need I say more?

text:
This has become my go-to recipe. I still add my own touches which are NOT figure friendly but make it ohhhhh soooooo good. I cook bacon and crumble it up in the batter, i also use the bacon grease instead of veg oil and I sometimes cut the milk back and add a can of creamed corn. I also cook it in a cast iron skillet that is preheated in the oven so it sizzles as i pour the batter in. It gives it a wonderful crust. We eat it with just butter, apple butter or other toppings after we've had our chili! AWSOME!

text:
Perfect!  This is so easy and delicious, I never even need to try another cornbread recipe.  Cornbread tends to fall apart easily so I like to make it into mini-muffins, which I bake at the same temp (400) for only 7 minutes.  A dab of butter on the top and it's the perfect bite-size piece!  I've successfully cut the recipe in half and in 2/3 with no trouble.  The recipe as written makes about 3 dozen mini muffins.

text:
Excellent. I used 1/2 the sugar and it was still sweet enough.    The batter was easy to make, directions easy. I baked it in my grandmother's iron cornbread form (looks like corn forms).  Took it out at 18 minutes and let set untill cooled, about 1 hour.  The cooler it got, the easiet it was to take out. You could make this and let it sit all day. Loved this.  Tastes just like an old-time recipe. Thx

Delicious cornbread.  Flavor was just what I was looking for, but I wanted something a little less crumbly.  It went over well with my family, but they thought it fell apart too easy.  Once it cooled, it sliced up nice.  I'll make it again, but I'll add a little extra oil to see if it holds up a little better when it's hot.  We like to eat it right out of the oven, with plenty of butter melting away on it.   It was absolulely perfect for crumbling on top of a bowl of beans.

This is a really great cornbread. I grew up eating savory cornbread but my husband likes sweet so I tried this and we love it! I made a double batch but I left the sugar the same. I thought it was perfect but my hubby thought it could have been a touch sweeter. Next time I'll probably add a bit more sugar.

country:

text:
This cornbread is absolutely delicious.  We used to just make cornbread out of a box and top it with butter and honey, which was pretty good.  This cornbread doesn't even need any condiments on top, because it is so sweet, flavorful and moist.  I made it last week to accompany some squash turkey chili, and my partner said it is the best cornbread he's ever had.  He has extremely discriminating taste, and is an amateur chef himself, but has requested that I make this cornbread at least once a week.  Also, he took a big slice of it to work for lunch the next day and ended up sitting next to someone else who also had brought homemade cornbread.  When she saw that hers was much denser, flatter and drier than his, she said, "well, mine is homemade," (as though that excuses bad food!) and he just said "oh" and sat back to revel in the glory of this fantastic bread :-)

text:
This cornbread was so easy to put together, but the results were first class!  One bowl preparation, the ingredients were spot on and stuff I already had on hand, and I easily adapted them to muffin format.  I added a couple tablespoons of honey because I was looking for a sweeter pairing with my spicy chili, and it was so, so good.  The crumb was moist and delicious, while the outside had a great crunch.  It made 12 perfectly sized muffins, which I baked at 400 for fifteen minutes.  Yum!  This is my new go-to recipe for cornbread.  Try it with the honey, you'll love it!

text:
This was ok, but no more than ok. The flavor was ok. The texture was pretty crumbly, like to the point where there was no hope for cutting out a wedge, slitting it half, filling the middle with butter, putting it back together, and then eating it. And if you can't butter your cornbread, then it's not really cornbread :-) It loses a star for being so crumbly, but it keeps 4 for taste, because the taste really is good.

text:
You've found it....the perfect recipe for sweet cornbread. I used 1/2 cup of sugar and it was definitely noticeably sweet, but I feel like anything more would be like a muffin. I cut down on baking powder to about 2 1/4 tsp and used a pinch more oil for added moisture. I filled up a muffin pan and baked until golden brown. Perfection! They were gone before the rest of dinner was. This is now my go-to cornbread recipe. I recommend making them in muffin form rather than in a pan for easy serving and convenient storage. These are FABULOUS cut in half with butter spread on a each half.

None
country:
None
text:
Very good!!  My recommendation is cook it in a oven safe, non-stick fry pan. First prepare recipe exactly as described then heat up frying pan (medium) on stove top and let two tablespoons of butter boil away water and begin to brown.  Cover edges of pan with butter and pour batter into hot pan.  Immediately, put pan in oven and bake as indicated, just cut about three minutes off time.  Bread will have a tasty, buttery, "caramelly" crust and is heaven.

text:
Loved this recipe because these ingredients are pretty much staples in most homes.  I made these following changes (after reading other reviews) and came out with GREAT tasting corn bread!
I did add another egg (for a total of 2), added about a tsp of vanilla, and added   2 tbsp of butter (because I was afraid it  would be too crumbly as others had problems with).  The end result was a moist middle and crusted top and a slightly sweet bread.  My preference is that I'd rather have sweet then bland corn bread.  I cooked this in a round glass and needed to cook it a total of 45 minutes.  I had this with chili beans from this site and was a huge hit!  I will use this over and over.

text:
Due to kitchen limitations, I had to cut the recipe in half. I opted for 1 single-serve cup of applesauce and 3 tbsp of canola oil instead of the recipe's oil and egg.

With a few drops of vanilla extract added to make it fragrant, the cornbread was beautifully golden after 15 minutes.  The inside was soft and sweet, and the edges were crunchy from the pan.  I'd make this again.

text:
Wonderful recipe.
I built a potluck main-dish around this cornbread recipe.  Follow the recipe as directed.  Pour 1/2 the batter in the bottom of the baking dish.  Layer ground turkey, corn, grated cheese, olives, mild peppers, and sprinkle a bit (to your liking) of taco seasoning mix.  Top with the remaining batter.  And bake.  (You may want to add a few more minutes to the baking time.) People were wanting to know who made the dish.  Then, when I got back to my desk, there they were, e-mails asking for the recipe.

text:
Really great recipe, but try this variation: Use very finely ground (stoneground) cornmeal or corn "flour" instead of usual cornmeal. Use one stick unsalted butter melted in 12 ounces of light cream, in place of oil and milk called for in recipe.  Decrease baking powder to one tablespoon.  Use two eggs, instead of one.  Mmm Mmm Mmm! Wow!

text:
Good recipe!  I made some changes of my own to sweeten and moisten it even more...my substitutions:
1.  Increased to 3/4 cup of sugar
2.  1 cup of buttermilk (substitute for the milk)
3.  1 cup of cake flour (substitute for the all-purpose flour)
4.  1 cup of cream-style corn

Yummy!

text:
Excellent cornbread! I used exactly what the recipe called for except a 1/8 cup extra oil and it turned out moist and light. I soaked the corn meal in the milk for 10 minutes and then mixed the batter with a hand mixer for 5 minutes to add some air to make it light and fluffy. It was just sweet enough, but not too sweet. I was a hit at the chili dinner. The guys wanted to take it all home, including the recipe.

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2332222
Display Name:
Jennifer B.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
29
favoritesCount:
98
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simply WONDERFUL!  My family LOVES this recipe.  I am allergic to wheat, eggs, and milk, so I substitute a gluten-free flour for the wheat, Ener-G "Egg Replacer" for the egg, and Vance's milk substitute for the milk... and it is fabulous.  I substitute turbidino sugar for the white sugar to give more flavor, and don't cook this bread a second longer than 20 minutes.  I also found that corn-meal varies from brand to brand as to how course it is, so try different ones to see what you like.  I also tried making this with corn flour rather than corn-meal, and the end result is much fluffier and almost cake like.  I liked the smoother texture, I think I'll try half corn flour and half corn meal next time.  Also, not sure how well this freezes if you make it with wheat, but since I substitute gluten-free flour, it's fabulous microwaved after being saved in pieces in the freezer.  Yum yum yum.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-03-29T22:36:10.67

text:
Excellent sweet cornbread, exactly what i was looking for.  Really good!
I did however, make the following changes, just because I had the stuff laying around and needed to use them.  I added two medium sized ripe bananas to the mix and once poured in the pan, I topped off the bread with about a cup of toasted coconut.  I baked it at 400 degrees but in a greased 10x15 baking sheet for 20-22 minutes.  It came out more "desserty" than regular cornbread, but it was fantastic nonetheless.

text:
I had to make some changes owing to personal taste and what I have on hand: I used white cornmeal (I don't like yellow), 1/4 cup of sugar (growing up we never put sugar in our cornmeal), and I always substitue powdered milk for regular milk in recipes (it's cheaper!).  I threw in some cheddar cheese and it tasted great!

This was amazing.  The sugar amount was perfect for us and it was SOO light and fluffy.  This is THE recipe for me!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVED this!  It was the perfect cornbread consistancy.  I made several changes suggested by previous reviewers and it turned out to be the best cornbread we have ever had.  Here are my changes

1.  Soak cornbread in milk for 15 minutes
2.  add 1 egg
3.  add 2 tablespoons butter to batter
4.  decrease baking powder to 2 3/4 tsp
5.  add 2 tsp oil to pan and heat it up in oven before adding batter

100% yummy!

Deenar

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing! First time I made any kind of bread from scratch.  I cant believe how easy this was!!!  I did decrease the sugar to 1/2 cup, the salt to 1/2 tsp, the baking powder to 2 1/2 tsp, and increased the oil just a tad after reading the other reviews.  One big pointer: I made the first batch exactly as stated (with the above modifications) and it was PERFECT. But the second batch, I was making for thanksgiving party of 30, two lasagna size trays, so I multiplied by 5 (60 servings).  The outside cooked faster than the center, so I had to decrease the heat to 300/325 and cook for a little over an hour.  So, just mind that you need to decrease cooking temp and increase time if you increase the servings to avoid having burned-on-the-outside/raw-in-the-center bread.  The toothpick test works really well.  My co-workers would have liked it sweeter, but for me the decreased sugar was perfect. Thanks for the easy recipe!!!

text:
I have tried many cornbread recipes looking for the sweet flavor that I have loved so much in southern cooking.  This cornbread was delicious, a perfect balance between the flavors of the cornmeal and the sugar.  I personally like a denser cornbread so I would suggest using only 2 tbsp of baking powder (cuts down on the salty flavor, which is a good thing to me, but if you like it salty you would want to compensate with more salt).  All in all, a delicious cornbread, a recipe that I will use from now on!

I made corn muffins with this recipe! It was terrific! I used skim milk, the two eggs that others suggested and olive oil. They did not crumble, and were really yummy! I did put less sugar in it (about 1/2 cup) and thought they were plenty sweet with just that! My whole family gives it 7 thumbs up :)

text:
This has to be the best cornbread I've ever tasted, homemade or store bought.  I actually make muffins out of them and they are sweet and moist.  Most of the recipes that I have tried are either too dry or too bland.  This recipe however is both sweet and moist.  I do reduce the amount of baking powder to two teaspoons as recommneded by some reviewers.  I also add a 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla extract for a slight vanilla taste as well adding some homemade vanilla sugar sprinkled on top of the batter prior to putting the pan into the oven.  A GREAT recipe!

text:
This cornbread is the best - moist but not greasy, sweet but not too sweet. I sort of compromised between this recipe and the similar recipe on my canister of cornmeal. I cut the sugar to 1/2 cup and cut the baking powder to 2 teaspoons. Also used a 8x8 pan, easier to cut in pieces. The second time I made it I found out (by accident) that you get a really great rich texture if you undercook it, let it cool a little, and then finish baking it. This also worked really well on my undercooked banana bread - every time I had some I stuck individual pieces in the toaster oven for a few minutes.

I made it but made one change.  I used cornflour instead of cornmeal.  I had to bake it longer though, not sure if that was because of the change I made of if the recipe itself needs tweaking.  But I cooked it 25 minutes, it was not done.  Gave it 5 more minutes, tried to cut it, it was doughy still in the center.  I put it back in for 10 more minutes.   Then it was perfect, and not a bit too dry.  Nice and moist and sweet and very good recipe.  I making a note of my changes in my own recipe book.

text:
Wonderful Corn Bread! I posted my photo of them, as well.
 I doubled the recipe, and put a total of 5 TBSP of Baking Powder, per other reviews- I also added a 1/2 tsp of baking soda, some vanilla and a dollop of sour cream for some extra moisture.  
I think next time I will do less flour, and more corn meal, for me it was a little too cake-like.  I prefer a grittier, more traditional tasting, corn bread.  It was still delicious with Great Northern Bean soup recipe from this site.  5 stars from me.
    I hate reviews that make alterations but mine were based off of other reviews—except for the vanilla, which I add to pretty much everything that isn’t a savory dish

text:
This has been my go to cornbread recipe for over a decade. It may be too sugary for some people. I cut the sugar back to half a cup. Leave the batter to rest in the pan  for 10 minutes prior to baking. It allows the cornmeal to absorb the liquids and lets the gluten rest.

text:
This recipe is so delicious, my only regret is not finding it sooner! My man dime(guy that I'm dating/10 across the board lol) is obsessed with cornbread and lucky me, I'm obsessed with baking AND cornbread! I made these last night and I'll be having to make some more in the morning because the rest won't last tonight! I followed the recipe as is(ingredients wise) but made a few changes! :

I made them as muffins, I was able to get an even 12! I used 2 TBSP per muffin and baked @ 400°F for 18 mins. I left 6 plain and added blackberries to the other 6. I used 2 blackberries in the middle and one on top. Lastly I lightly dusted all 12 muffins with cinnamon right before I baked them! they came out perfect I was in such shock! next time I want to try it with buttermilk. I loved the blackberry addition so I'll do that again but add some vanilla beans yuuuuuuum!

text:
I'm no cornbread expert. I didn't grow up with it. Famous Dave's muffins are my favorites, to give you an idea of what my tastebuds prefer. That being said, I loved this. I did use butter rather than oil (as I will again), and left out about a T of sugar (but not next time!) It was moist for cornbread, but with some crumbling as it should. I let the cornmeal soak as others said. My 9 inch round pan was ready at 20 minutes. I wish I had lined the pan with parchment paper and cut back a little on the baking powder, but it was still delicious!

text:
AMAZING! I cut the recipe in half and it made six muffins that took about 20 minutes to bake. Used Bob's Red Mill cornmeal and Bob's Red Mill vegan egg replacer. I still used the equivalent of one egg along with oat milk and a little extra oil based on the other reviews. I also added a little extra baking powder and a splash of vanilla since I wanted them more cake-like. These were amazing! I didn't even need honey because they were really sweet.

userID:
11173663
Display Name:
Laura Mitchell Hamann
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
33
favoritesCount:
37
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1135954.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good base recipe but for the most moist and sweet cornbread I use the following adaptations:  I put a half a stick of butter in a cast iron skillet and let it preheat in the oven while the oven heats up.  Work quick so your butter doesn’t burn.  I leave about an eighth of a cup of the milk out and add vinegar to the one cup line (or use a cup of buttermilk instead if you have it) I let that sit while I whisk the dry  ingredients together.  I left a half a teaspoon of the baking powder out and added a half teaspoon of baking soda in its place to get a better reaction with the vinegar.  I also blend a can of cream style corn until  smooth and add all the wet ingredients to the dry ones, put the hot skillet out add the mixture and bake as directed.  Perfect!
Review:

userID:

Display Name:
Nikki Robinson
isPro:

3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1499485.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe. I followed one person's comment and decided to make it exactly like the recipe before making changes . The only thing I changed was the amount of oil since most people agreed it needed a little more because it was too crumbling. I doubled the recipe but instead of 2/3 cup of oil I used just under a full cup. In my opinion it is perfect. I'm glad I doubled it because we finished most of it. But since I doubled it the outside cooked faster than the center so I covered with aluminum foil and continued baking it so it wouldn't get too dark. I'm making my second (double) one now. I don't know if I'll ever go back to jiffy Oh yeah it's also delicious in a cornbread stuffing.
Review:

text:
This is my go to cornbread recipe. My sons and husband love it. Before initially making it I surveyed several reviews and ultimately incorporated three simple substitutions for awesome cornbread. I use buttermilk instead of regular milk, melted butter rather than oil, and I substitute brown sugar for white sugar.

I have been making this recipe for several years, and figured I ought to write a review as it is a household staple.  My husband LOVES this, and won't eat anyone else's cornbread.  I make precisely as written except I usually preheat my cast iron skillet and bake it in that.  Last year we went to a friend's for a long weekend, and had cornbread one night.  My husband requested that I make this, as she doesn't do sweet, but she insisted her husband and kids would want hers ... That didn't go well!   Rave reviews always - and making a triple batch with the chili for Halloween tonight.

text:
I enjoyed this recipe a lot,  I looked through some other reviews and I soaked my cornmeal in the milk for about 20 minutes and did not have a problem with it being too crumbly. 
-used 1/3c white sugar and 1/3c brown sugar 
-used buttermilk instead (only because my milk had expired a week early apparently )  
- baked in a sprayed 9x13 pan for about 15 minutes and it was a perfect golden brown and tasted great!

text:
Loved it! Super fluffy! I have to be gluten free, so I subbed AP Gluten Free Flour (rice blend based) for the AP flour. I added half a TSP of xanthan gum as a binder. I didn’t have eggs, so I used 3 TBSP of mayo. Also used buttermilk instead of regular milk (again, that’s what I had on hand...). Wow!!! Just WOW! The rest of my family doesn’t have to be gluten free and none of us has to be egg free, but this was amazing!! Some people will read this and say that I changed the recipe completely. Haha! You have to have a good place to start, Guys, and this was it! A keeper!!

text:
I used this recipe to make cornbread in my Nuwave oven because my oven is out. The only modifications I made were to cook for 15 minutes vs 20-25 in an ungreased pan (the one that came with my Nuwave). It turned out delicious, just a hair moist on the bottom, but not wet or soggy. You can probably add 2 more minutes to fix this.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve used this recipe before and along with 2 others, it’s one of my favorite cornbread recipes.  I made bbq ribs and you just can’t eat ribs without cornbread as one of your sides; plus I wanted to finally test out my Copper Chef muffin tin. Okay, I pretty much followed the recipe as is, except for these changes: I used 1/2 cup of sugar instead of 2/3, 3/4 tsp salt instead of 1, 2.5 tsp of baking powder instead of 3.5, and 1/2 cup of oil instead of 1/3 (following another reviewer’s suggestion that a little more oil make it less crumbly). And since I was using a muffin tin instead of baking pan, I baked at 375° instead of 400.  I got 11 muffins out of this recipe. They came out just right and was nice and moist and not too crumbly. Yum right out of the oven with some butter.  FYI, I did not spray one of the cups to test out if it was really nonstick and it is. I could not

I have made better from scratch that was super moist and crispy edges but thats a family recipe i know from heart. I also added very little corn in my mix that was left over from dinner.. Not even a half a cup, whatever i had left.

text:
After reading several reviews,  I decided to make this exactly as written, except I did increase the oil by about 2 teaspoons.  It was perfect. Sweet, but not too sweet. It rose the perfect amount.  It stayed fairly solid and moist. My husband is Not a cornbread fan, and he ate 2 pieces. 
Another thing I like is that it uses regular milk instead of buttermilk.  I didn't have to buy anything special to make it.

country:
None
text:
Big raves for this one.  I tweaked it to be gluten and dairy free.  Here were my modifications.

* Used GF flour
* Added 1 cup of roasted corn to a 12 serving recipe
* Used a coarser version of cornmeal
* Divided the sugar half white/half brown
* Used almond milk, added 2 tablespoons of Apple Cider Vinegar and let stand for 10 mins.  This is the vegan version of buttermilk.  The milk will separate and look like it's curdling. Just stir it before you put it in.

After making corn muffins from a box brand (around since 1930!) and having them look like small white hockey pucks (along with the same texture), I decided to try a real recipe. Will be my go-to recipe from now on!

userID:
9147600
Display Name:
jnnpppnk
isPro:

followersCount:
1

madeRecipesCount:
54
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/819833.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Reduce  sugar to maybe a round 1/2-cup or less using 1/3 c white and 1/3 c brown sugar.  Let the cornmeal soak in the milk for 10-15 minutes before mixing with the other ingredients.  Replace veg oil with melted butter.  Add just a smidgen more salt and a 1/2 tsp vanilla.  Also add just a little bit more oil so it's not quite so crumbly. OR, bake muffins (only 15 mins).                                                                                                           MUFFINS: Pour the batter into muffin pan lined with cupcake papers almost to the very top of the liners.  Bake at 375 degrees (with a convection oven the heat is usually 25 degrees less than the normal temp, otherwise bake at the suggested heat of 400 degrees).  Cook to perfection with nicely browned tops @ 400 degrees for 20-23 mins using a toothpick to test for doneness.  A medium grind cornmeal that is a little more course makes the cornbread more like a true “comfort food”.  If you don’t like that extra crunch then use a finer grind. EVERYONE loves this- it is always on request

text:
This Cornbread was great! Simple, flavorful, sweet, and still had that cornbread texture.  I read the reviews and swapped out the oil for the real butter and also 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white sugar.  I baked it in a pie pan for about 25 minutes. This goes great with beans (aka beans and cornbread) and would be delish just as a side with butter or dessert with honey.  Thanks for the advice and will definitely make again!

5

I think this is the best cornbread I've ever had! I made it in a cast-iron skillet and served it with some bean soup in the crock-pot to take to a job site for our crew working in cold wind and weather. The crew never used the butter, honey, or jelly on it - they loved it straight out of the pan. Seriously delicious

text:
when I first made it the batter was too thick. I had to add a half cup of milk to it. maybe its supposed to be thick for a cake type thing? but out of all the years ive made homemade cornbread from scratch it is never that thick. I think its because cornmeal and sugar absorbs most of the liquid...anywho I also added a tablespoon of honey and 1\2 cup sugar to make it more diabetic friendly. other than that I love this basic recipie and my hubby does too. its delicious.

text:
Made this recipe with some tweaks to use for my stuffing. We loved it so much I'm sharing my changes. I added an extra egg since my eggs here are mostly medium size; so two eggs. I halfed the sugar on two batches and used even less sugar for the third batch. That makes a cornbread plenty sweet for stuffing. This recipe is so good, hence the 2K+ comments, that it's my new go-to for cornbread anytime!

text:
I was out of butter but really wanted to have cornbread with my chili tonight. This recipe worked great, after reading reviews I reduced the baking powder to 2 tsps but I think next time I will try the recipe as is because mine were a little dense. This one will be going into my recipe box for the next time I am out of butter! My tip for any cornbread recipe - add lime zest and serve with salsa, you won't regret it!

text:
This cornbread has great flavor.  As others have mentioned it is crumbly.  It goes very quickly from undercooked to dry.  Be sure to watch it carefully.  The second time I made it I lined the bottom of the cake pan with waxed paper then sprayed it with cooking spray.  It came out without breaking by doing that.

text:
I doubled it and used half dark brown sugar and half white. Cooked in my 12 inch cast iron skillet preheated in 400-degree oven. melted half a stick of butter in the pan before pouring batter in and added 1/2 stick melted butter to wet ingredients - let the batter sit 15 minutes to soften cornmeal- - was delish warm with butter and honey. will make again. Made a skillet full (I could have filled it more)  + 10 muffins.

text:
Excellent cornbread recipe!  I also substituted buttermilk for milk (since I had it in the house)  and soaked the cornmeal in it for a few minutes. Using melted butter instead of oil gave it a nice buttery taste, but not too much that you can’t add a little on top when it’s cooled??.  Baking it for 25 minutes was perfect, nice and moist, but fully cooked. It had a lovely golden top and the bottom had a slight crisp on the edges. Enjoy!

text:
This was a hit with our family.  My husband said it was not his mom's cornbread and that was good, lol.  Her's was dry and mealy according to him.  

Btw, 9-inch round pan (63.6 sqin) is almost exactly the size in area of an 8-inch square pan (64 sqin).   So use 8-inch square pan if you don't have the round 9-inch pan handy.
Hubby calculated it for me using the pi x r^2 formula.  ;D

text:
This is absolutely my go-to sweet cornbread recipe. To elevate slightly, I suggest cooking in a cast iron skillet - preheat skillet in the oven while oven preheats, put in a decent amount of butter or bacon fat (couple tablespoons), and poor in your batter. When it’s done, it will turn neatly out of the pan with a to die for crispy crust.

I left a review  for an alternate version of the recipe. The directions were great. Also, Instead of using all raw sugar you can use half the amount required and mix it with half coconut palm sugar. It cuts down on glucose but still ads sweetness. But the salt may show up more in flavor because palm sugar is definitly not the same. Just mix the two sugars if you are watching your figure.

text:
First time I make any recipe, I make it precisely as the recipe states. After that I can make adjustments. This was (possibly) my first time making cornbread and I base this on the recipe as is.

As is, this is simply delicious. I just ate a third of the pan (made mine in a cast iron skillet)

For my own taste preferences, I'd probably add a little less sugar. Believe me, it is DELICIOUS as is, but I want mine a little less sweet. I've seen adjustments others have made and I may experiment with using butter instead of oil, or buttermilk instead of milk, just to see what happens. But as of now, this is my go-to recipe! Thank you, Bluegirl!

text:
I’ve made this recipe several times, but have had to go gluten free in the past year. I made this bread again for a party and substituted Bob’s Red Mill GF 1:1 flour for the regular flour. I also used melted butter in place of the oil and cultured buttermilk powder instead of milk. The end product was incredible, if not better than the original non GF one! Everyone loved it and I can guarantee that had I not said it was GF, no one would have known!!!!

text:
I made this for a 4th of July party, and it was a home run, thanks.  I made a few tweaks you might also consider; I only used about 1/4 cup sugar and instead used about 1/2 cup of TJ’s frozen super sweet organic corn niblets.  I used about 1/2 melted butter and 1/2 veg oil.  And I threw in a generous amount of thinly sliced fresh jalapeños.  I also used small batch hand rolled European style butter, local raw honey, a little lemon zest and made some really awesome whipped honey butter (leave it out a few hours so it’s really soft and spready )

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Four stars because I made several changes. 
I only had about 3/4 cup cornmeal so I added 1/4 cup pre-cooked cornmeal (Masarepa) to get the full cup. 
I used 1/2 cup of sugar instead of 2/3 cup. I whisked together all the dry ingredients first. 
I was out of eggs so I used 1/3 cup of applesauce. 
My husband has a dairy allergy so I used substituted 1 cup of oatmilk and I used 1/3 cup of coconut oil instead of canola oil. The coconut oil was  soft but not melted. 
After whisking in the wet ingredients the batter is kind of thick/dense but still pourable. 
Baked in a glass pyrex greased with cooking spray, 25 minutes at 350. 
It was perfect. Just the right amount of sweet and rich, not dry.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-04-05T20:07:23.513

text:
I love this recipe and have been making it for a long time. I don’t change anything on the recipe itself, it is perfect as-is. The only thing I do differently is I bake it in my cast iron skillet. I put the skillet in the oven while it’s preheating plus an extra 10-15 minutes. Then I pour in my batter and bake as normal. The top is still golden brown but the bottom and sides form this chewy delicious crust than helps hold the bread together after you slice it. This would be a good recipe to use as a base and then add jalapeño or put your own spin on it. We like it so much I don’t want to change a thing!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good basic recipe. Twist it to whatever you want. I've had some good cornbread with jalapeños. 

I baked in cast iron muffin pan. Before adding the oil to the ingredients, I preheated the oven with the pan in it and with about 1/2 tablespoon of the oil in each cup. Then dumped the rest of the oil in the ingredients. Second batch, added a little oil to the cups with the pan still hot. 

I also added about 2 tablespoons of honey. 

Baked 15 minutes in the muffin pan.

text:
I only made two changes and they were by accident, one I used white "self rising" corn meal mix before realizing what I did, and two after noticing I was using the wrong cornmeal I did what someone commented and used a ratio of one cup of flour to  one tsp of baking powder and it seemed to work out. I just figured if anyone else was as silly as I was in not reading it right the first time, this info could come in a little bit handy. And the resulting loaf made my family very happy anyway, yeah it was crumbly but isn't all cornbread crumbly?

text:
Gave it a 5 although I made changes as was suggested by others. 2 tsp baking powder, 2 tbls more of oil, add 2 tsp of vanilla.
Baked these at suggested temp for 10 mins in muffin top pans. Some call them whoopie pans. Filled them up. Nice crust on the bottom, very little crumb and very flavourful. Served with liquid honey. GREAT, even my wife liked them and she is not fond of cornmeal anything.

I added an extra egg, converted the milk to buttermilk, substituted brown sugar for white, and melted butter instead of using oil.  it came out very well and took approximately 17 minutes and 34 seconds to bake @ 185 degrees Celcius.  it was not dry and not too sweet. it tastes very good,  with a little butter melting over a hot piece, it becomes great.

text:
Easy cornbread that you'll never need boxed again! SO loved it and had more for breakfast. 

I followed some changes recommended - using melted butter instead of oil, and less baking powder.  I didn't have enough baking powder left so that worked out. I also used brown sugar (personal preference) instead of white and only a 1/2 cup instead of 2/3.  My SO prefers muffin and so I baked a dozen in silicone muffin cups at 400 degrees for around 20-24 minutes.

userID:

Display Name:
MizzWycked

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/933020.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a rule I don't care for cornbread, never have. But this.....this cornbread was incredibly yummy!! Super easy to throw together. Took just a few minutes to mix the ingredients in my KitchenAid, but I could just have easily used a bowl and spoon. I incorporated all the dry ingredients first, then threw an egg into the cup of milk and gave that a quick stir before mixing with the dry ingredients. As per other reviews I did up the salt to 1 1/2 teaspoons to balance the amount of sugar. I buttered the bottom and sides of my cast iron skillet and it baked to perfection. I did let mine go an additional 5 minutes (for a total of 15 minutes) to get a golden brown top. It came out super moist, not too crumbly and just a bit crunchy on the outside. This will definitely be my go-to recipe for cornbread!
