text:
This corn bread is just the way I like it!  Sweet, golden moist and crumbly. It reminds me of the one they serve at Montanas restaurant.   Another reviewer suggested using 1/3  cup white sugar and 1/3 cup brown, as well as replacing the oil with melted butter, and I think these changes made it perfect for my taste. I made them in mini  square loaf pans and they were done in 18 min.
Edit* forgot to mention that I also let the cornmeal soak in the milk for about 10-15 min as well.

text:
This recipe is going to become a staple in my house! They were eaten up so fast! I kept all the ingredient levels true to the recipe, but it is a tradition in my family to add some whole corn kernels to corn bread as well. We usually make box mix. Adding half a can to a home made recipe was the best addition ever! As another reviewer had mentioned cooking them in a muffin pan, I went with this method. Lightly sprayed the paper muffin cups. The corn bread cooked evenly and came out of the paper easily. I topped them with honey and butter. SO GOOD!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I prefer this as a muffin, as it is on the sweet side. Cooked each tray of muffins for 11 minutes at 400 degrees. Switch oil or butter made no big difference or 2/3 c. sugar vs 1/3 c. sugar & 1/3 c. brown sugar for more of a dessert muffin (served drizzled with warm preserves or honey over a broken muffin) . I do suggest soaking corn meal in the milk while prepping the rest of the batter and gently folding into mixture. Lumps are Gold!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I used a couple reviewer tweaks, like 1/3C each brown and white sugars, subbing butter for vegetable oil, and soaking the cornmeal in milk while measuring & mixing together other ingredients. I also chose to put my batter in cupcake papers and bake in a muffin tin at 400 degrees for about 15 min. I think I could have baked it shorter or at a lower temp as they came out really delicate/crumbly, but other than that they were a hit! Just the right sweetness: MIL makes sweet cornbread, and while it is a hit with the grandkids, I find it TOO sweet. This recipe's sugar content is JUST RIGHT! Thanks for the post!

Loved this recipe! Because I never have what I need on hand, I've replaced a few things and really enjoyed the result. Substituted the vegetable oil for coconut oil. text:
I thought I would give this a try since I can't have my flour tortillas with chili any more, recently gone Gluten Free.  I substituted Bob's Red Mill 1 to 1 gluten free flour and Maseca corn flour for the corn meal otherwise followed directions. My family is not big on corn bread so I don't make it often even though I love it. I think the finer texture of the corn flour is what did the trick for the rest of the family. There was nothing left over to put away.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making cornbread and it was a success.  Reading all of the reviews this is what I did for my recipe: 
 I brought the milk to room temperature before adding it to the dry ingredients. I did use a little bit more oil to help with the crumble issue.  I used 2tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp salt and reduced the sugar to 1/2 cup.  I ended up using a mixture of white sugar and brown sugar because I accidentally ran out of white sugar. It did not seem to have any major impact on the taste. I greased the pan and added butter and put it in the oven to heat up prior to adding the batter.

Yum! I preheated the oven with my cast iron pan in it. Beat egg prior to mixing in liquid ingredients. I used raw cane sugar and a whole grain white flour. Once the batter was made I pulled out pan and dropped in about a tablespoon of butter to coat the pan. Once melted I poured in the batter and in the oven it went.  Ended up going for the full 25 minutes.  Will make again.  Thank you for sharing!

text:
I've been making this recipe for years now. The only change I've made is to double the recipe. My family loves this cornbread.  My grandson and his friends devour a double batch in minutes, When I'm baking it, they find any pretext they can to hang out in the kitchen as they wait for it to come out of the oven.
In ADDITION TO BEING A WIFE, MOTHER, AND GRANDMOTHER, I'm also a Boy Scout leader and have made this cornbread in Dutch Ovens countless times while we are camping. It is a "go to" recipe for our troop. It's become one of the recipes I use when teaching boys to cook over an open fire. If you haven't tried this, I strongly recommend that you do. It's amazing!

text:
Yummy! I made very few changes to this recipe. I used buttermilk instead of milk. That's the only substitution. I cooked it in my trusty cast iron skillet that I put in the oven while it was preheating. When the oven was ready, I rubbed a little oil around the inside of the skillet and poured the batter in.  The cornbread turned out sweet, the way we like it, with a nice crunchy crust from the cast iron skillet. We ate it with a southwestern soup recipe from this site, and the whole skillet of cornbread was eaten! Everyone loved it. This one's a keeper for me. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Wow this is an excellent cornbread.  I took the suggestion of another rater who also gave it five stars, and used 1/3 cup of white sugar and 1/3 cup of brown sugar.  I  also spared about 2 tablespoons of oil and added 2 TBSP of melted butter to equal the 1/3 cup.  I wanted a more buttery flavor.  I may omit the oil all together and just use melted butter next time but it turned out perfect and not at all crumbly. Just buttery and sweet, and picture perfect.  Thanks for submitting this terrific recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
High altitude certified! I live at ~6200ft, and I chose this recipe because it used so much baking powder (for the "puff"). I followed the directions exactly other than decreasing the sugar to 1/2 cup, and increasing the oil to a little less than a 1/2 cup.  I used a 9in spring form pan, and it was done in 20 mins. Came out of the pan, no problem after 10-15 minutes of cooling. The extra oil helped it stick together, and the crumb was excellent. Had a sweet, really simple flavor, and a texture that stood up to some butter, honey, and dipping it in chili. Great recipe for picky eaters or having a cornbread that does not overshadow a main course. LOVE IT.

text:
Couple changes in that I used organic sugar from cane instead of white  sugar and reduced that amount to half cup instead of 2/3cup and added 1/4 cup of honey to mix also. Additionally I reduced oil amount by 2tbs. And replaced with 1/4 stick of unsalted butter which improved flavor balance  nicely. This recipe made 12 regular sized muffins with no waste when filled to just shy of 1/4 inch from top of muffin cups.. Just like Boston market which is my barometer for tasty cornbread. Eat them up yum! ??

Display Name:
Fair Cooker
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3113362.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've just started doing some gluten-free baking, and just grabbed this off the 'net as a starting point for a cornbread recipe.  With only a few changes, I got the most amazing, fluffy, gluten-free cornbread on the first try.  I used rice flour instead of white wheat flour and added 2 tsp xanthan gum.   My personal taste preferences had me leave out the salt and cut the sugar to about 1/3 cup.  I used much less oil, too, maybe 2 or 3 Tbsp of light olive oil.  Didn't have any whole milk, so I mixed evaporated milk with water, 50/50.  In fact, it came out so light and fluffy, reminiscent of angels food cake, I might use less xanthan gum next time to get something a little denser and less springy.  Or I might make it the same way again -- it's good!
Review:

5

This has been the only corn bread my husband has liked since I first tried it almost 9 years ago! 
If there is any left over from dinner, I have it in the morning with butter and syrup, warmed in the microwave with just a splash of milk--pure comfort food. 
The recipe is perfect made just as directed.  I learned the hard way to be sure to use the 9 inch round cake pan.  For some reason it bakes perfectly in that as opposed to using say an 8 inch square or 10 inch round.
Thanks for great recipe.

text:
This is my family's favorite cornbread. I do have to modify it because I have a child allergic to eggs. I substitute 1/3 cup of applesauce for the egg, and this is the first recipe I've found that holds together well even without the egg. It's also deliciously moist - almost creamy inside, and it stays moist for days (if it lasts that long!)

text:
I usually just make cornbread from a box mix but found myself with cornmeal that I wanted to use up so I decided to give this a try.  I don't think I will buy box mixes again.  I followed the tip to use 1/3 c. brown sugar and 1/3 cup white sugar, and I let the cornmeal soak in the milk for 15 min.  I was able to make ahead and put it in the fridge for a couple hours before I was ready to cook it.  So easy and my family ate it up!

country:
None
text:
Good recipe. I mixed fine and coarse cornmeal for a little more texture. Very good and not too sweet. When it took it out of the oven, I took a quarter stick of butter and slowly rubbed it across the top gently to let it melt in while it was still hot. 
I would make it again for sure. I would say check it at 18 or so minutes to figure how long you might need to finish it. I checked it at 22 and it was starting to burn in my oven. Got it just in time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it twice as the first time one of our animals climbed on the counter and ate most of it the first time. What was left of the first one which was slightly over baked was better than the second one which was stodgy. It was nice, but not amazing. I used the linseed trick instead of egg (1tbs crushed linseed soaked in 3tbs water for 30 minutes) which does make baked goods flaky, however this one was slightly stodgy but also a little gritty. I think that what I would do in future is set the batter aside for half an hour to allow the cornmeal to soak evoke baking which would do away with the grittiness. Will def try again though.

text:
I used 1/3 c. white and 1/3 c. brown sugar (b/c I ran out of white and even though the white was in the pantry I was too lazy to go refill it)... I baked it at 375 degrees in a convection oven for 17 mins (I like my top a bit crunchy!) in muffin tins sprayed with some non-stick spray. Added a dash of vanilla, a tad more oil to avoid the crumble and voila!  I have baked this several times before without changing a thing and it's  good either way! Next I will experiment with corn kernels, jalapeño peppers, and maybe some cheddar as add-ons!

whoopeegirl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super yummy!  Super easy!  Super fast!  This is some great cornbread.  The first time I made it, it was a bit too sweet for us.  Cut the sugar in half, not sweet enough.  Used 1/3 cup plus half of a 1/3 cup (I don't math haha)... just right.  I've also made it missing ingredients:  extra light olive oil or shortening instead of the veggie oil, 1/4 cup extra milk when I didn't have an egg, and it came out great.  I didn't have a "crumble problem", don't know why.  I do let mine "rest" a bit before I stick it in the oven.  Best way to cook it:  grease a cast iron frying pan with shortening, put it in the oven, turn the oven on and let it stay until it’s at the cooking temperature.  Pull it out and pour the batter in... it should sizzle a little.  It’ll give you a nice crispy crust and a tender interior.  Best way to eat it... crumble into a glass, pour in the milk, drizzle with a little honey.  Deeeeelish!

text:
I thought some homemade cornbread would go great with my husband's famous fried chicken, so I tried this recipe. I've never made cornbread before but this recipe is so simple and delicious. Whether you're a beginner or a pro you'll LOVE this recipe. If you're skeptical about using sour cream don't be, I'm not personally a s.c. person but I followed the recipe and it turned out extremely moist. With some recipes the bread can come out dry and crumbly but not this one! I have written it down for future use and with Fall approaching in the next few months can't think of anything better than this to go with chili or any cool night with soup.

text:
My Grandmother loved what she called "Johnny cake" and after she came to live with us then got too sick to make it herself she taught me to make it. I was just a kid but I was happy to do the chore because she shared it with me. 
I haven't really made it sense she passed away.... (Have you ever done math in you head and came up with an answer that couldn't be right so you wrote it out and it turned out it WAS right) She passed away 30 years ago! (1984 Please check my math. I'm still not completely sure it's right) I think she got the recipe from HER grandmother who called it Johnny Cake around the time of the US Civil War
I made this recipe the other day and it came out too crumblely so I tried again adding two eggs instead of one and it came out perfect.
  I miss my grandmother so I'm going to go enjoy my fresh "Johnny Cake" AKA Cornbread.

text:
I should start by telling you that I don't follow baking and or recipes exactly. I read a few and put what I like together and hope it works... I liked how simple this recipe was but I don't keep milk in my fridge, so I in turn used a dollop of plain Greek yogurt and cup of water. I used brown and white sugar, 1 tsp of chia seeds, a hefty sprinkling of frozen organic corn and instead of vegetable oil, melted Earth Balance soy free. I was a little wary but this is by far the best sweet corn bread I have ever had!! Eat with caution because it may disappear in front of your eyes!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is AMAZING! I used it for corn muffins, and they came out just like they would at any bakery. Many people say to cut the sugar, I agree ONLY if you're making savory cornbread to go with say chili. Otherwise, as a sweet treat, keep the sugar, and add maybe 3 tbsp of brown sugar. I substituted the oil with melted no salt margarine  and used evaporated milk. I also threw in maybe 1/4 cup pancake mix and 1/4 cup more corn meal. Like many suggested, I also added a 1/2 tsp of vanilla extract and a pinch more salt.
Although I made a few alterations of my own, I'm sure following this recipe to the T would make equally as great muffins.
This is a keeper!

This recipe was the best! I took some of the advice that some of the others had listed on here. I added 1 cup of sweet corn. Used 1/3 cup of white sugar and 1/3 cup of brown sugar, a little cinnamon and a little vanilla flavoring. I also used mini muffin pans and made sure to grease them well. I did let them cook with the oven on for about 10 minutes and then turned the oven off but let them stay in there to finish cooking. They came out perfect! Not a single 1 crumbled. Definitely will make again. Everyone loved them.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been baking cornbread for my family for over 35 years.  The recipe I was using was very good, but had too many steps to accomplish a great end result. I wanted to make a change to a simpler recipe and decided to try this one. I wasn't very impressed at all. My original recipe separated three eggs where I mixed the batter with the yolks, then had to whip the whites into a meringue & fold into the batter. This recipe used only one whole egg, but was a bit on the salty side, including the small amount of batter left behind in the bowl.  The finished product came up tasting salty and dry, even with an addition of vanilla that I added after the wet ingredients were incorporated because it lacked flavor.  I'm going back to my standby recipe, which has never disappointed me.  As the old saying goes, "if it isn't broken, don't fix it!"

text:
I love this recipe but like to tweek a bit myself, I use fresh ground flour I use whole wheat flour made with hard white wheat, the sweetener is honey powder, but last but not least I make my own fresh ground cornmeal made with white popcorn kernels it makes a wonderful cornmeal wow what a difference fresh ground ingredients makes. My wife for the most part dislikes cornbread but she loves mine. The flour and cornmeal I sift with a very fine mesh sifter. It makes for a very fine powder both the flour and cornmeal which makes the cornbread very light and oh so good!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1194771.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this cornbread yesterday to have with chicken and white bean chili.  We LOVED it.  I did make some modifications due to our dietary needs.  I have been searching for months for a recipe that would hold up to substituting whole wheat flour for white, since that is all we use, and we have found a winner.  :)
I took a reviewer's advice and soaked the cornmeal in the milk for half an hour before mixing the ingredients.  I used organic sugar and cut the amount to 1/4 cup.  I also used 1/2 cup butter to avoid the dryness some reviewers complained of.  
The result was a moist, slightly sweet and delicious cornbread.  Thanks so much!

text:
Nice recipe! I didn't have enough milk, so I mixed some sour cream and water for the "milk". Added a ting more salt & some vanilla as suggested because I know how I like my food. Also added a little more oil as suggested in hopes of curing the crumbliness but it didn't work...probably because sour cream is richer than milk. However, even with the above, cornbread was awesome and fluffy. I think this recipe will be better using all milk versus my concoction, but it worked with just a bit of tang at the end. 4 stars because of crumbles. Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe yields a delicious sweet cornbread.  I have been using this recipe for several years and recently I have made a few substitutions to make it a bit healthier-- I swap the white flour with whole wheat flour, cows milk for unsweetened almond milk, unsweetened applesauce for the oil, a "flax seed egg" for the chicken egg, and I reduce the sugar just a bit (my substitutions do make it quite a bit lower in fat and also vegan for anyone that eats that type of diet).  The recipe turns out great when made as the recipe indicates or when made with my substitutions.  Another quick note-- when I use baking powder that has aluminum my foods often get a bitter taste to them, if anyone has this issue I recommend you try using an aluminum free baking powder as that will likely clear up the bitter taste problem.

I have been using this recipe for two years! I haven't used jiffy mix in two years!. What does that mean this is a great tasting dish. Display Name:
Hannah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/921810.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time trying cornbread and what a way to dive in! I can't imagine looking for other recipes. This was easy and straightforward, scrumptious and light- utterly delicious. I used milled corn that I sifted, and I still got some crunch. I might try it next time without sifting and see how it turns out. I used half a cup of sugar, but it was still a tad too sweet for me; will use just a little less next time. However, the sugar does make it a great snack on its own, so no worries. I mixed powdered milk and water to get the quantity of milk called for, but in no particular ratio; I just made sure it was really creamy. I did add more corn flour and all purpose flour, about two tablespoons each. It was only when I had it baking that I saw some reviewers had advised 2 teaspoons of baking powder, but with the 3 and a half, it turned out fantastic. Loved it and will definitely keep making it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been my go-to cornbread recipe for the last two years. I am gluten-free, so I swap all purpose flour for Bob's Red Mill gluten free all purpose flour mix. I also use 1/2 c. of Stevia instead of the sugar, and haven't noticed a difference in taste. I sometimes add a chopped jalapeno and 1 cup of shredded cheddar, and it goes great with chili. It seems to turn out best when I mix the ingredients, then let the batter sit for about 15 minutes. Turns out great in a muffin tin or my favorite way, in my grandma's old 9" cast iron skillet.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy and yummy, I doubled the recipe but was low on milk so I substituted 1/2 of the milk with 1/2 plain greek style yogurt. Raves from the dinner party! Success. Earlier in the day I mixed the dry ingredients and the wet ingredients in separate bowls and let the bowls sit until just before dinner. 1/2 hour before dinner I mixed them together by hand and I used preheated cast iron skillets instead of the cake pans.  The skillets were doused with a bit of olive oil and tossed into the 400 degree oven until hot, I divided the doubled recipe into the two hot skillets and returned them to the oven.  I was busy having fun so I don't know how long it took to cook but when I remembered them, they both were perfectly puffed and golden brown.  I let them cool just a minute and cut them into big wedges to serve with dinner. Best cornbread I've ever made, I can see many ways to dress up the recipe with savory or sweet ingredients.  YUM*****

text:
Great recipe, thanks for sharing. I followed another suggestion and used 1/2 white and 1/2 brown sugar. The only reason I rated it 4 instead of 5 was, as other users have said, it was a bit on the crumbly side, making it a bit messy to eat. Next time I will try the trick of soaking the corn meal in the milk to see if that resolves the issue. I might also add, I made these in muffin tins and 23 minutes at 400 was spot on.

Just made this tonight for the first time and it was fabulous!!! Actually it's the best cornbread I have ever made. I didn't have cornmeal, but I did have polenta which is just a coarser grind. I finely ground it in my vitamix blender and used it. Yum! I baked my cornbread in a convection oven. It came out wonderfully crisp on the outside and sweet and moist on the inside. This will now be my "go to" cornbread recipe.

text:
I was looking for a good sweet cornbread to go with a beef-and-bean chili recipe. I was skeptical of this recipe at first, because some of the reviews described it as "cake-like" and, being a Southern gal, I prefer a firm, "crisp" cornbread. Well, I'm a convert now. This is the only cornbread I'll ever make. It's the perfect combination of firm and delicate, and just melts in your mouth.

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this for a going away party and everyone, especially my cousin who ate almost 1/2 of it, LOVED it. 
I read some of the other reviews and used 1/3c brown & 1/3c white sugar in addition to 1/3c powdered milk + 1c water for the 1c milk (I was curious as to what it'd taste like because I wasn't sure if I had powdered milk or creamer haha). 
When I was mixing up the wet ingredients my 4yo & 5yo were eating the sugar so I added (probably, I eyeballed it) about another 1/4c or so of white sugar to replace what they had 'sampled'. 
Since I was making it for a crowd I doubled the recipe and used a 9x13, baked at 400 for 35min, although 30min would have been a little better since the top was a little browner than I would have liked.

userID:
744467
Display Name:
Susan Stone
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/479741.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this 5 stars because it has wonderful flavor and texture, and although my first attempt did not come out perfectly, it was because of what I did to it.  First off, I used agave nectar (¼ c) instead of sugar; also used sifted bread flour instead of regular white flour (both because of dietary restrictions).  In addition I cut the baking powder to 2t per some reviews.  The only problem I had was that it didn't rise as tall as I would have expected, and that may have been because of the bread flour.  Anyway, this recipe is a definite keeper!  I will be making this again, using the full amount of baking powder.

I have made this again, this time substituting ½ cup honey mesquite flour for ¼ cup of the cornmeal and ¼ cup of the flour.  That makes a great recipe even better.  The mesquite adds sweetness to the cornbread so ? cup of sugar was plenty.  If you want mesquite flour you can find it online - it's a bit expensive, but worth it (I cheat - we have 2 honey mesquite trees and I make my own flour).

text:
I have a similar recipe that I make as muffins and my kids love it. I too use a mix or white sugar and brown sugar, but then I add a teaspoon of vanilla. For just a bit more flavor, I decrease the sugar to a half a cup total and then when the muffins are still hot I brush them with a mix of melted butter, a teaspoon of brown sugar and a half a teaspoon of vanilla. You could also use honey or maple syrup.

text:
I love cornbread! I grew up in the south yet no one in my family EVER made cornbread from scratch -- it was always the boxed Jiffy mix (which I love!) So this was my first recipe on my own. I used unbleached white wheat flour as well as olive oil in place of veggie. The only thing I changed was the sugar amount (I used ~1/2 c) but I could've gone with the whole 2/3 c. Overall, it tasted very good. It was more crumbly than I usually like but I chalk that up to the olive oil (?). I'll definitely make this again!

text:
This is the BEST cornbread! I used to add extra oil and sugar to the box mix TRYING to get this flavor and texture, but this is quicker and easier and better.

It took me about five minutes to mix up the batter, and then I poured it into a scorching hot cast iron skillet and baked for about fifteen minutes. It was moist, sweet (more like cake than southern cornbread) and had perfect crust and crumb.

This is SWEET. You'll hate it if you like a more traditional southern cornbread, but for this yankee with a sweet tooth it's THE perfect recipe.

text:
Great basic recipe. Fantastic texture. Made with butter in place of oil. 2/3 cup total sweetener, but used 1/6 c honey, and rest was 1/2 sugar, 1/2 splenda. Used buttermilk instead of milk. Cooked in cast iron skillet, heated in the oven ahead, then wiped with butter flavored crisco to grease, poured in batter and cooked at 400F for 16 min. Will use this as my go-to cornbread-perfectly sweet and easily adaptable to a sweeter or less sweet version dependent on how much honey/sugar you use.

Made this recipe because I need cornbread for my Christmas dinner(cornbread stuffing).  I made it with whole-wheat flour, white cornmeal(that's what I have, I use it to make Kenyan Ugali), used half white sugar and half honey granules to make 2/3 cup,  a bit less oil than 1/3 cup(ran out of it).  It turned out very nice and moist indeed.  I am very pleased, I would make it again.  Next time I'll try incorporating corn, butter, buttermilk...etc.

I was afraid they would be a little dry form the wheat flour, but they were PERFECT! This is my NEW cornbread recipe, with the substitutions!!!

This was nice. A little more liquidy (when mixed) than other cornbread recipes.   To make vegan-version, use Silk (soymilk) in place of milk, use closer to 2.5/3 teaspoons of baking powder and omit the egg. I also used soybean oil and it can out divine! My vegan-recipe-hating-fiance had more than his fair share of this!

text:
Love this recipe - it's easy to knock off in a hurry when I need bread for dinner!  And, everyone likes it, too.    My substitutions include butter-flavored crisco instead of vegetable oil & soy milk instead of cow's milk (we have a milk allergy in the house).  I also use some brown sugar in place of the white sugar most of the time.  Every once in a while, I'll add some frozen sweet corn to the batter before cooking, as well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for cornbread to go with the pot of chili I had made, but instead of cooking it in a regular pan round or square I made it in a star shaped silicone pan so each point could be a cut slice...I don't know if it was the silicone or what but I set my oven to cook for 25 min like the recipe calls for 20-25 min...and it was not long enough. It looked done and the toothpick came out clean, but when I flipped it onto a plate to cut and serve just under the crust ontop was still sticky and the botton was still doughy and was still really light in the center the edges looked great and crunchy...so I put the cornbread in for another 10 minutes and it was completely baked through...so if you have a convection oven and use a silicone pan, set your time for at least 35 minutes and definately do the toothpick check...but in the end the taste test was great my family enjoyed it very much...I made the recipe as is did not add a thing but I did soak the cornmeal for a bit...thank you

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/280188.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe!  The original recipe is sweet and moist and very tasty.  I make a few alterations, however.  I substitute whole wheat flour for the white, which makes the bread a little more filling and adds fiber.  I also use dark brown sugar instead of white.  I find this enhances the flavor while keeping the sweetness of the bread.  I use safflower oil specifically, because I like it's lack of flavor and that extra kick of vitamin E.  This might sound strange for those not accustomed to whole wheat, but once you're used to the flavor it's hard to go back to regular white flour!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this cornbread several times now and just noticed that I had not reviewed it previously. This is a delicious, sweet, light cornbread. I like it sweet so I use a rounded 2/3 cup of sugar, a smidge more salt and 1/2 a teaspoon of vanilla. I don't use vegetable oil at all, always canola and I use an extra tablespoon for added moisture. I bake it in a dark non-stick 9" x 9" square pan so I lower the temperature to 375 and add 3 - 5 minutes. The result is terrific.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing! seriously a favourite in my house now. I did tweak slightly, but not much. I took the sugar down to 130g (too sweet otherwise), the salt to 4g and the baking powder down to 10/11g. I also used 80g of melted butter instead of oil - makes the cornbread very moist and fluffy. Also just before putting into the oven i sprinkled a little bit of brown sugar on top. It bakes just below the the surface but remains crunchy so when you bite into it, it adds a nice texture... Deffo more of a dessert in our house but fantastic all the same!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best cornbread I've had in a long time. I had been using the recipe on the Quaker Corn Meal can, and the cornbread was too dry for me. So my husband ate them. My buttermilk had spoiled, so I decided on this recipe because it didn't require buttermilk.   I made it per the recipe except for a couple of modifications. I had only 1/4 cup of corn meal left in the can after I measured the 1 cup. So I poured it in. I also add 1/4 cup of honey and 1/2 cup of sugar as suggested by other reviewers, and used 1 tsp of baking powder, and omitted the baking soda.  This recipe is a keeper. The extra corn meal add a little texture which I like. The corn bread is also moist, sweet, and light.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cornbread's stellar as it stands. I've made it twice following the recipe, and I've yet to get a complaint. In fact, people go back for seconds. I was concerned about it being too sweet, but it actually works out for me. I did alter the recipe though, which might have cut off some of the sweetness. So, in my version, I used melted butter instead of vegetable oil (don't have any in my house) and buttermilk for my milk (personal choice). It wasn't too sweet at all.  Also, the crumbliness is a slight problem, but there's a really easy solution to that: let it cool. Give the cornbread like a 15 minute cool out of the oven in the pan, and it won't crumble on you. You'll get nice wedges like in the photo.

text:
Wow. I"m usually very very picky with sweet cornbread recipes, but this one took the cake -- literally and figuratively :)  I had my apprehensions making this recipe because when I tasted the batter, it was too sour (probably from the baking powder).  When it baked, the sourness dissipated to reveal a very sweet and very moist cornbread.  I baked it in an 8x8 pyrex and came out fabulous.  I'd make this again.  Great for Thanksgiving and with a roasted chicken dinner. Thank you for sharing.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1393044.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made only one change to this recipe and that was to only add 1 T baking powder (3 t).  My cornbread came out light, fluffy, sweet and moist.  I baked in a 9 in clay Pampered Chef baker (pretty close to using a cast iron skillet) which I greased liberally with shortening and placed in the oven while it was preheating.  I convection baked it at 400 degrees and it was beautifully golden.  (I'm not sure how long it baked.)  I wish I had taken a picture of it; it was that beautiful!  I saw one commenter said it wasn't cornbread, it was a cornmeal cake and I kind of agree with that, but I don't think that makes it bad at all--just different.  I have always preferred unsweetened cornbread but I really did enjoy this variation and I thank you for the recipe.  You can bet we'll be making this one time and again.

Update 10/25/10:  This continues to be THE ONLY cornbread I will make.  My husband is now VERY  disappointed when I make something from a package :o)  Perfect just as it is!  Easily doubled with no problems too--bake in a 9x13 pan.  Works great in cornbread stuffing too!

text:
Great cornbread! I've made this 3 times now and it is officially my go-to cornbread recipe. You can make it sweeter or less sweet. If you really want to make it sing, cut the white sugar a little and add about a TB of honey (no more) to the wet ingredients, then blend it all together. The flavor is subtle and yet somehow amazing.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always have missed the cornbread my grandma used to make; couldn't find a recipe that was even close; somehow always found thime somewhat lacking...  Until now, that is!  This is a beautiful recipe for those who like sweet cornbread.  Did double the recipe and add half a teaspoon vanilla extract; but otherwise; kept it exactly how it was.  Was great as a kids helping recipe; too; as you can just stir it all in one bowl; don't have alot of steps; and the kids can stir it as much as they want and it doesn't affect the results at all.  Served it with some sweetened cream beat until quite stiff (not to butter; but just before it starts to change texture a bit); a good dallop on top when just out of the oven...  Divine!

country:
None
text:
This is an awesome recipe for cornbread.  My tweaking - I decreased the sugar to 1/2 cup Splends, used 2 eggs and used 6 Tbsps of meltted butter instead of vegetable oil.  After baking for about 23 minutes, I let it cool for about 8 minutes before cutting and it was perfect - each piece held together very well. I served this cornbread with homemade bean soup for lunch today.  A perfect combination!! No more store-bought cornbread mixes for me. This will be my standard cornbread recipe from now on!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good basic recipe - sweetness is perfect for those (like me) who like a middling sweet.

Definitely soak the cornmeal in milk 10 minutes prior, or use a finely ground meal.  

Added an extra egg to a doubled recipe, and the crumbling remained under control.

If you do one thing - decrease the baking powder!  I only added 3 tbsp instead of 3.5, and it still turned out too sour. I'll drop to 1 or 2 tsbp. only next time.

text:
The picture makes the cornbread look nice and soft. Mine wasn't. Oh well, it tasted pretty good. My mom liked it. It'd be a good idea to take the butter out of your refrigerate when you start baking the cornbread. Then, spread the butter on the cornbread while it's hot out of the oven so it will melt. I would make just enough for one meal. If you leave it for the next day, it gets hard. I'll probably make this again.

I followed the recipe exact although I did have the cornmeal sit in milk for approximately 15 minutes and I added slightly less sugar...and made two batches.  The first batch I made wasn't as sweet as I expected bc the second batch which I had made (which was smaller muffins...I made them as cupcakes/muffins) was a lot sweeter.  Overall, this recipe was good despite the fact that it was quite crumbly as other reviewers have said.  My boyfriend had said it tasted good but tasted a bit flour-y.   I think I'm going to add less flour and more cornmeal next time I bake this...

Based on what other reviewers submitted, I reduced the sugar to 1/2 cup and I used just over 2 tbsp of baking powder.  This recipe is definitely a keeper.

text:
This is a classic cornbread recipe. I was so glad I found it because I had a great recipe for cornbread that I lost - but this one replaced it.

The only things I changed are: I reduced the amount of sugar to 1/2 cup. Also, I used sucanat (evaporated cane juice) instead of white sugar which is so bad for one's health. I also used whole wheat flour and soy milk instead of regular milk.

With or without the substitutions, it's a fabulous cornbread recipe! I won't use anything else.

text:
This is indeed very good cornbread. I think it's lower in fat than other cornbreads listed here. I used this as my starter recipe. I added canned corn and some cooked onion. It became a delicious savoury cornbread. I baked them for about 20 minutes in muffin tins. They tasted and looked perfect. I liked how the bottom was golden brown. Like others did, I used half a cup of sugar and 2 tsp of baking powder. It was quite sweet still for my taste. Wonderful recipe. Perfect for beginners.

Display Name:
MONOU

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the other reviews, I too used only 1/2 cup of sugar and 2 1/2 tsp. baking powder.  Actually, I didn't have baking powder, and no all-purpose flour.  So I used 1 cup self-rising flour, 1/2 tsp. salt, and in place of the baking powder, 1/4 tsp. baking soda, 1/2 tsp. cream of tartar, and 1/4 tsp. cornstarch.  I also added 1/2 tsp. vanilla.  It worked out great.  I made it twice, for a party in class and for my study group.  But I wish I had had a chance to try a little more than a piece (1 1/2 of the recipe) before making it again--I would still cut back on the sugar, maybe to 1/3 cup.  Then it would be nice to have with honey--just the way I like it.  But with these adjustments, I FINALLY found a great cornbread recipe!!  Thanks Lori.
Review:
Rating:
4
